importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The GPEI anticipates a 30 percent budget reduction starting in 2026, which directly impacts the feasibility of ongoing polio eradication activities.
The $1.7 billion funding gap is projected through 2029, marking a critical deadline for maintaining global polio eradication efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The funding shortfall spans from 2026 to 2029, defining the period during which reduced financial support threatens progress on global polio eradication.

keyTakeAways: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI) faces a $1.7 billion funding shortfall through 2029 due to reduced foreign aid, particularly from the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom.
The WHO's director of polio eradication, Jamal Ahmed, warns that a 30% budget reduction in 2026 will mean certain activities—such as vaccination campaigns—will not be feasible.

To respond, the GPEI will focus resources on high-risk regions like Afghanistan and Pakistan, where wild polio cases are reported, and will scale back operations in lower-risk areas unless outbreaks occur.
The initiative will adopt fractional dosing, using only a fifth of a standard vaccine dose, to stretch vaccine supplies while maintaining protection against polio.
Polio persists in Afghanistan and Pakistan, with 36 reported cases of wild polio in 2025, and 149 cases of vaccine-derived polio reported globally, including in Nigeria.
Vaccine-derived polio occurs when weakened viruses in vaccines are shed and mutate, spreading to unvaccinated populations, highlighting the importance of continued vaccination and surveillance.
Despite declines in polio cases since 2024, the global threat remains due to asymptomatic transmission and persistent endemic regions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Global Polio Eradication Initiative (GPEI), including the World Health Organization and the Gates Foundation, faces a $1.7 billion funding shortfall through 2029 due to reduced foreign aid from major donors such as the United States, Germany, and the United Kingdom. This financial crisis, projected to include a 30% budget cut starting in 2026, threatens critical polio eradication activities. In response, the GPEI will focus its resources on high-risk areas like Afghanistan and Pakistan, where wild polio cases are reported, and will implement cost-saving strategies such as fractional dosing to stretch vaccine supplies. The article also highlights the ongoing threat of both wild and vaccine-derived polio, with 36 wild polio cases and 149 vaccine-derived cases reported in 2025, underscoring the importance of continued vaccination and surveillance despite declining case numbers.
title: WHO warns $1.7bn funding shortfall threatens polio eradication efforts
